div1.p: Havard recalls Gorgas' hesitance in accepting the conclusions of the Reed commission and his continuance of the expensive disinfection of fomites. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Valery Havard to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 19, 1925
div1.opener:
From Col. V. Havard - Med. Corps U.S.A. Ret'd.
Chief Surgeon, Division of Cuba.
Fairfield. Conn.
April 19. 1925
My Dear Colonel Kean,
div1.p:
Your letter of March 19, with editorial
from Military Surgeon, were duly received and
certainly read with great pleasure and interest. Many
thanks for them. This editorial is quite worthy of
your pen and in every way admirable. I must
apologize for not replying as promptly as I should.
A combination of illness and old age had a decided
inhibitory effect on my correspondence, even with
friends for whom I have always entertained the
highest regard. Please forgive this apparent indif-
ference.

We are certainly fortunate in having such
an organ as the Military Surgeon, but particularly
so in having the benefit of your experience and great
abilities in its management. I hope that the burden
will not be greater than you can bear and that you
can get all the assistance you need.

I had already read, with entire approval, your
article in the N.Y. Times of April 27. 1924, and had
certainly intended to offer you my congratulations at
the time, but I presume the combination of disabilities
mentioned above made me neglect to to go.

I think you are doing our friend Gorgas full
justice and, at the same time, rendering also to
2
others the credit which is their due. It is
probably impossible to tell every thing and please
everybody, but no one can accuse you to say a
word not strictly according to facts and truth!

I remember everybody's surprise at Gorgas'
attitude in hesitating so long to accept the con-
clusions so clearly brought out by Reed, especial
ly in continuing the useless and expensive disin-
fection of fomites until August. In reference
to this I may perhaps bring back to your mem-
ory the part played by Surgeon General Sternberg
in jogging up Gorgas' mind. I remember distinctly
calling on General Wood, early in April. 1901,
and submitting my draft of Circular no. 5 which
had become necessary. He was quite perplexed over
the subject of fomites, fearing that the stoppage
of disinfection, altho apparently the correct thing
to do, would be too sudden a change, and that he
was not yet quite decided to assume such respon-
sibility. I suggested to send the draft to the Surgeon
General (Sternberg) and to be guided by his advice.
Gen. Wood thought this a good idea, and the
Circular was forwarded at once to Washington.
Evidently Sternberg had already made up his mind
on this question of fomites. He replied without
delay and with full conviction that, after the ex-
periments of the Reed Commission, doubt was no longer
possible and that the Circular should be published,
3
and it was published at once (April 27)
Any hesitation after that on the part of Gorgas
was incomprehensible and unpardonable.

I am sorry to say that my publisher
(Wm Wood and Co.) declines to bring out another
edition of my Military Hygiene, or any other M.
H. He says there is no money in it, or not
enough to warrant the trouble and worry. Such
being the case the necessary expenses, it appears to
me, must come out of the author's pocket -- where
there is none -- or still much better, a new plan
adopted for this and similar works, namely. They
should be declared official, prepared by a board
of 2 or 3 medical officers and printed by the Governm't.
This seems to me a subject well worth looking into.

My daughter Aline is still under treatment at
the Walter Reed Hospital for arthritis. This does not
seem to interfere seriously with her literary work.
Perhaps you have come across her “My Basal Metab-
olism” in the Atlantic Monthly for February (unsigned)
Her books are mostly intended for young people but
appear to be as attractive to gray-headed folk. She
would be very glad to see you should you happen
to visit the hospital.

I am delighted to see the spring flowers and
again listen to our familiar birds. Winter has but little
comfort for old men and I wish the summer would stay with
us to the end--

closer.salute: With best wishes, always sincerely yours.
